title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [5–12? july 1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [5–12? July 1869]
text: I got your letter walter dear to daytoday George is staying homhome now to superententsuperintend the big pipe to be laid from the engine house he is better i think since he come he had to walk from the foundry to the hotel even days in the heat to his dinner a mile he says it was from the foundry and when he got there he couldentcouldn't eat he has lost several pounds in flesh and looks rather bad he says he would like to lay off awhile but he cantcan'tit is very pleasant this thursdayThursday morning and i feel better that i have felt for the last few days george started this morning a little after 6 ocloo'clock he has to walk to atlantic stAtlantic Street and take the cars for east new yorkNew York so he has to have his breakfesbreakfast earlywell walt as you say there aintain't much to write about only i thought you would think stangestrange if i didentdidn't write) O walt aintain't them 15 cts bills nice george bought them all but two of me i suppose they will soon be in circulation) you didentdidn't say if Burroughs was returned) i look for hellen price and her mother to daytoday they were to come the last of this week and its cool to daytoday i haventhaven't heard how nobody is this morning he is to be the ingeneerengineer of the bridge he has been very low but i suppose he is living)no more at present you will come next month love to mr and mrs oconor Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [5–12? July 1869]
